name: Edict: Forced Relocation
desc: Relocating your populace to other colonies might sound slightly unethical, but it is definitely the most effective way to grow a small colony.

name: Edict: Industrial Incentives
desc: It's an age old mantra - spend money to earn money.

name: Edict: Labour Restrictions
desc: Less time worked is more time spent to realize ones dreams. Less time worked is also less time spent earning money for you.

name: Edict: Subpopulation Cleansing
desc: Purging undesirables from a planet is gruesome work. It is also a lot harder if you cannot remove them via strategic measures due to urbanization.

name: Edict: Wartime Lockdown
desc: Military drafts, mobilization of the wartime industrial complex and full planetary lockdown can drastically increase the defensive potential of a world - at a cost.

name: Edict: Customs Control
desc: Routing all systembound traffic though a single polity will make a few people very, very rich, while leaving the other planets to pay for it.

name: Edict: Forced Labour
desc: The realities of the sector do not allow for such trifles as human rights, and a conscripted workforce is a cheap workforce. Your populace is likely to have a different opinion.

name: Edict: Hard Deadlines
desc: Extremely short deadlines on ship production lead to increased output, increased turnover rates, accidents and quality problems.

name: Edict: Exact Clearances
desc: Forcing a focus on quality over quantity during ship production will result in fewer, but better hulls - a luxury not every faction can afford.

name: Edict: Single-Child Policy
desc: Growth is not always beneficial - to stay under the radar, a smaller population size might be more effective than a larger one.

name: Edict: Trade Incentives
desc: Buy and sell anything your heart desires! Allowing independent traders to open up their inventory for sale in dedicated areas without additional infrastructure does not have a major impact on colony income, but still allows you to buy from them.

name: Edict: Mandated Overtime
desc: Mandating a 16 hour work day and conscripting labour from non-essential industries will hasten construction projects beyond belief. Anything else is unlikely to get done, though.

name: Lawless Subpopulation
desc:
A significant part of the population on this planet is composed of active and former pirates, cutthroats, "independent" polities that do not adhere to local rules or fugitives invited by the favorable living conditions a privateering license can grant.

Good relations with the more disreputable factions of the sector can have very positive effects on this colony - as long as a Privateer Base is present.

name: Industrial Ruins
desc: Old buildings of unknown function and origin can be found on $market. The machinery seems to be mostly intact and is far more advanced than anything the post-collapse sector could ever hope to construct.

name: Cryorevival Disabler (hidden)
desc: internal hidden condition for riftGen special functions

name: WorldWonderCondition
desc: internal hidden condition for world wonder functionality

name: Orbital Parade
desc: A parade fleet holds orbit over $planetName, its contrails catching the light. Children point skyward; others watch in silence, weighing the cost of a ticket against a monthâ€™s wages. The sight even draws travelers from far-off ports. It is both a display of strength and a measured advertisement of wealth.

name: #Engineered Plague
desc: $marketName has been contaminated by a ferociously virulent engineered plague. Extensive decontamination procedures are required for all inhabitants and exports, significantly increasing operating costs.

name: Self-Replicating Minefield
desc: An old, autonomous replicating minefield surrounds this planet. Despite their age, the mines continue to replenish themselves and are very much in working order. The internal IFF appears to be based on the polity controlling the planet.

name: Domain Artillery Station
desc: A Domain weapons platform looms over this planet.
